newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israel, PLO trade blame in Gaza explosions.
newsitem.headline: Israel, PLO trade blame in Gaza explosions.

text.p: Two Palestinians were killed in blasts in the Gaza Strip on Tuesday which Israel said were botched suicide bombings aimed at Jewish school children.

The PLO charged Israeli troops were behind one of the blasts which came against a backdrop of crumbling Middle East peace moves and Israeli accusations Palestinian President Yasser Arafat has failed to curb militants in areas of the West Bank and Gaza under his control.
In separate incidents in the West Bank, Israeli forces shot dead two Palestinians as violence flared for a 13th straight day over the building of a Jewish settlement in Arab East Jerusalem.

The Israeli army said two bombers died in separate attacks near isolated Jewish settlement enclaves in self-ruled Gaza. Palestinians conceded one of the dead men blew himself up but said the other was killed by a bomb or grenade thrown from an Israeli jeep. No Israelis were hurt in the incidents.

Near Kfar Darom settlement, a Palestinian dressed in military uniform was ripped apart and five Arab taxi passengers were wounded in the morning explosion on the main Gaza-Rafah road near Deir al-Balah refugee camp.

"In Kfar Darom area an Israeli military jeep hurled a grenade or a bomb at (Palestinian) passersby killing one and wounding others. This is information that we have collected from passersby and victims," Ahmed Abdel-Rahman, secretary-general of the Palestinian cabinet, told Reuters.
The Israeli army rejected the Palestinian account.
"It is absolutely incorrect. There were two suicide attacks and two bombs," an army spokesman told Reuters.

Earlier, Palestinian police officials said that a man with five kg (11 lb) of explosives on his back blew himself up on the side of the road at 7 a.m. (0400 GMT) about two km (1.5 miles) from the Jewish settlement of Netzarim south of Gaza City.
"Today's twin attacks ... are proof that the terror campaign continues," Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu told reporters.
"The terrorist organisations ... continue to understand they have a green light from the Palestinian Authority to perpetrate their savagery," he said.
Netanyahu said a PLO crackdown on militants was a precondition to any progress in peace talks: "It so far has not done so and if peace is to survive it must do so immediately."
The militant Hamas and Islamic Jihad groups denied they were behind the explosions, accusing Israel of ordering the blasts to sour relations between Hamas and the Palestinian Authority.

"This bombing was done by the Israeli intelligence and its (Palestinian) collaborators in an attempt to create an internal problem between the Islamic movement and the Palestinian Authority," Hamas official Sayed Abu Musameh told Reuters.

Israel Television said an anonymous caller claimed responsibility for the attacks on behalf of the Islamic Jihad and identified the two bombers as Abdallah Ramadan al-Madhoun and Anwar Ahmad al-Shabrawi.
The report said one of the militants worked for the Palestinian preventive security service in Gaza.
Both Gaza explosions occurred around 7 a.m., the time Israeli children leave two nearby Jewish settlements on buses for school, Jewish settlers said.
"We can suppose that the operative goal at that hour was school buses or settler commuters who go to work at that hour," Israeli Southern Commander Shlomo Yanai said.
Last month an anonymous caller told police Hamas had carried out a suicide bombing in Tel Aviv in which three Israeli women were killed. The PLO denies it has given a "green light" to militants.

In the West Bank town of Nablus, Israeli soldiers shot and killed Palestinian policeman Haitham Mansour, 20, during clashes between stone-throwing Palestinians and Israeli troops, witnesses said. Mansour was not in uniform when he was shot.
"The brain itself was outside the skull," Arab surgeon Husam Jamhara told Reuters. Hospital officials said five Palestinians were treated for live or rubber bullet wounds in the clashes.
Mansour, his body shrouded in a Palestinian flag, was buried later on Tuesday to a 21-gun salute and full military honours.

In a second incident, an Arab teenager identified as Kamal al-Zaro was shot dead in Hebron. The Israeli army said soldiers spotted several Arabs engaging in theft. It said all but one fled in a car and that troops shot him as he fled on foot.
"The suspect did not stop and soldiers fired at him," an army spokesman said.
